RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

2. 
According to Uzbekistan’s Constitution, every citizen is entitled to basic education, which 
is  provided  by  the  public  sector.  The  Government  requested  assistance  from  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to address key constraints in basic education development, including 
the  sustainable  provision  of  affordable  textbooks  and  other  learning  materials,  curriculum 
reform, and school library development. The Project is designed to address these issues. The 
project framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
A.

3.

secondary education continues from grades 10 to 12 and will be compulsory from 2010. Higher 
education consists of a 4-year bachelor of arts program followed by a 2-year masters program 
and  then  a  doctoral  program.  Basic  information  on  the  education  system  and  structure  is  in 
Appendix 2. 
 
In 2003/04, of the 9,727 basic secondary schools, 2,006 (20.6%) were urban. This figure

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

6. 
Notwithstanding the progress already made since the late 1990s, formidable challenges 
remain  for  the  Government  to  realize  its  long-term  goal  of  making  the  education  system 
consistent  with  a  market-oriented  economy  and  a  democratic  society  in  the  21st  century.  In 
basic education, the challenge is to improve quality and relevance, where textbooks play a key 
role  in  determining  student  performance.  ADB  approved  the  Basic  Education  Textbook 
Development Project (BETDP)3 in 1997 and has been initially successful in supporting textbook 
development  and  provision.  A  basic  education  subsector  analysis  with  a  problem  tree  is  in 
Appendix 3.  
 

1. 

Basic Education and Textbook Subsector Issues 

7. 
Textbooks  and  Curriculum.  In  Uzbekistan  textbooks  are  almost  the  only  form  of 
teaching and learning support provided for both students and teaching staff. Therefore they are 
a key material input in influencing quality and relevance of basic education. In 1998, as a result 
of  growing  financial  constraints,  the  Government  terminated  the  policy  of  free  provision  of 
textbooks.  While  most  parents  found  textbooks  at  full  price  unaffordable,  suppliers  also 
struggled  with  uncertainty  of  demand  and  credit.  By  2000,  serious  textbook  shortages  were 
being  experienced  in  many  schools.  In  2001,  the  BETDP  successfully  introduced  a  pilot 
textbook  rental  scheme  (TRS).  The  TRS  effectively  addressed  the  affordability  issue  by 
reducing parental expenditure on textbooks to an annual rental fee. The fee was approximately 
5  times  cheaper  than  the  total  purchase  price  of  a  set  of  textbooks.  Schools  and  parents 
strongly  supported  the  TRS  pilot,  which  achieved  a  collection  rate  of  93%.  As  a  result  of  this 
success, the TRS was extended nationwide to cover grades 2–5 and 9.  
 
8. 
National  coverage  of  the  TRS  to  include  affordable  core  textbooks  and  teacher  guides 
for all grades of basic education, except grade 1, is now needed.4 In addition, the institutional 
basis of the TRS needs to be placed on a sound footing so that the accumulated rental fees are 
professionally  managed  to  ensure  sustainability  of  textbook  and  teacher-guide  provision.  By 
2007,  centralized  funding  of  core  textbooks  and  teacher  guides  will  cease  and  textbook 
replacement  supplies  will  be  funded  from  the  rental  fee  balances  accumulated  in  school  bank 
accounts.  The  transition  from  centralized  to  decentralized  funding  and  from  central  to  school-
based decision-making will require careful planning and management. National monitoring and 
supervision  of  the  TRS  within  the  Ministry  of  Public  Education  (MOPE)  also  needs  to  be 
improved  and  institutionalized.  At  present,  the  Government  provides  support  for  the  socially 
unprotected—approximately  15%  of  the  student  population.  This  support  is  in  the  form  of  free 
textbooks  and  teacher  guides  provided  to  school  libraries  with  schools  in  rich  and  poor  areas 
receiving a similar proportion of free books. Targeting the poor must also be improved.

A  reformed  assessment  and  testing  system  is  central  to  upgrading  the  quality  of  basic

11. 
The Uzbek Constitution grants the right to citizens to education in their own languages, 
i.e.,  Russian,  Karakalpak,  Kazakh,  Tajik,  Kyrgyz,  and  Turkmen.  To  maintain  cost  and  quality

language  textbook  publishing.  However,  the  Government  has  had  difficulty  maintaining  the 
necessary  funding  at  the  required  level,  especially  in  times  of  fiscal  constraints.  A  review  of 
language of instruction (LOI) practices is needed to ensure greater equity and to contribute to 
overall system cost reduction.

stated  priority  of  the  Government.  However,  how  best  to  integrate  ICT  in  the  curriculum  to

ICT provision are yet to be fully explored. Current ICT support is short term, with little prospect 
for sustainability. The need to develop a practical, affordable, and sustainable strategy for ICT 
provision in basic education is urgent.

are  the  textbook  and  the  teacher.  The  situation  is  exacerbated  by  teachers’  limited  access  to 
alternative sources of information. A good school library is as essential for teachers as it is for 
students.  MOPE  already  recognizes  the  need  for  alternative  learning materials  to  support  and 
complement basic textbooks.  
 
17. 
If  learning  styles  are  to  be  changed,  low  cost, user-friendly,  well-stocked,  open  access 
school libraries need to be developed. Ideally, libraries should offer information to students in a 
variety of media. Internet access to wider information sources through library-based computers 
is  an  important  component  of  school  library  systems  elsewhere  in  the  world.  Before  a  cost-
effective ICT strategy for basic education is developed, low-cost compact disk technology could 
be  used  in  the  short  to  medium  term.  Meanwhile  efforts  should  be  devoted  to  developing 
suitable educational software in the Uzbek language.

variety of media. The provision of library-based computers with Internet access will also widen 
the  scope  of  information  available  to  students  and  teachers.  Thus,  the  library  development 
component  will  provide  genuine  opportunities  for  individual  and  small  groups  working  and 
conducting research, which in turn will encourage wider reading and thinking around curriculum 
subjects and the ability of students to explore and develop their own interests.

BASIC EDUCATION SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 

 
 
The Government’s stated long-term reform goal for education is to transform the system 
1. 
into one that is consistent with a market-oriented economy and a democratic society in the 21st 
century.  To  realize  this  aspiration,  basic  education  as  a  subsector  faces  the  key  challenge  to 
improve quality and relevance, as analyzed in the following (a problem tree is attached).  
 
2. 
Governance  and  Institutional  Constraints.  As  a  priority  in  the  overall  government 
reform agenda, basic education has received significant fiscal and other support over the past 
decade and managed to avoid the dramatic decline in enrolment witnessed in some transition 
countries.  However,  within  an  overall  highly  centralized  bureaucratic  system,  basic  education, 
like other subsectors, is still largely governed by rigid norms set by the central Government. For 
example,  most  items  in  the  annual  school  budgets  are  fixed  and  schools  have  discretionary 
spending authority over only a small portion of the budget. In all subjects taught, programs and 
standards set by the central Government strictly dictate the contents and time allocated for the 
subjects,  leaving  inadequate  freedom  for  schools  to  adjust  to  student  needs  and  local 
conditions. State norms fix student-teacher ratios countrywide, and schools have neither power 
nor budgetary incentives to strive for optimal use of existing resources. As a result, the system 
does not encourage nor support capacity building in planning and management skills. While the 
Mahalla  (local  community)  system  has  played  an  important  role  as  part  of  the  overall 
government social protection system, community participation and involvement in key decision-
making remains limited.  
 
3. 
To  address  equity  concerns  and  protect  the  poor,  the  Government  has  allocated  fiscal 
support  for  the  free  provision  of  textbooks  and  clothing  for  the  poorest  15%  of  the  school 
population. At present, this support is inadequately targeted because of the practical difficulties 
in providing compensatory budget support for areas with higher than average levels of poverty. 
The problem is also due to the unavailability of poverty indicators for raions and school, which 
are necessary to achieve better targeting.  
 
Currently,  the  private  sector  does  not  participate  in  the  provision  of  basic  education. 
4. 
State-owned  enterprises  dominate  publishing  and  printing  of  textbooks  and  educational 
materials. The nascent and weak private sector and the emergence of a competitive educational 
book market could benefit a great deal from continuing privatization, but first, the Government 
must  accelerate  efforts  to  create  an  equitable  environment  and  improved  access  for  private 
sector involvement in the textbook market. Growing competition in this subsector would lead to 
increased  external  efficiency  through  higher  quality  and  lower  prices  of  textbooks  and  other 
educational materials.  
 
5. 
Curriculum  and  Other  Educational  Policies.  Curriculum  reform  has  been  ongoing 
since 1991 and progress has been made in reforming state education standards and in reducing 
the  number  of  subjects  and  the  amount  of  specified  content  for  the  school  year  2003/04. 
Overall,  the  curriculum  remains  overloaded  with  an  undue  emphasis  on  factual  memorization 
and on repetitive exercises rather than on the development of key skills and competencies. An 
overloaded  curriculum  reinforces  didactic  teacher-centered  classroom  approaches  at  the 
expense  of  student-centered  learning  methodologies  because  teachers  must  rush  through 
classes to meet to meet the heavy content requirements, leaving no time for interaction with and 
among students. Such a curriculum also has high cost implications as each subject requires a 
textbook  and  each  book  has  far  too  much  extent.  As  the  cornerstone  of  an  education  system

suitable for the new millennium, comprehensive curriculum reform is needed as the centerpiece 
of the reform agenda for basic education. 
 
6. 
A  modernized  assessment  and  testing  system  is  integral  to  the  system  to  ensure  the 
quality of basic education. At present, tests in schools are graded by individual teachers in the 
lower  grades  and  noneffective  national  tests  prior  to  graduation.  Under  such  a  system,  no 
effective  and  reliable  way  is  available  to  assess  and  compare  the  quality  of  basic  education 
provided  on  a  national,  oblast,  raion,  or  school  basis,  and  no  way  to  compare  student 
performance year-on-year or internationally. Existing assessment and testing practices need to 
be  modernized,  together  with  curriculum  reform  to  ensure  an  effective,  fair,  and  transparent 
system that will support improvements in the quality and relevance of basic education.  
 
The current language of instruction (LOI) policy guarantees the rights of ethnic minorities 
7. 
to education in Russian, Karakalpak, Kazakh, Tajik, Kyrgyz, and Turkmen, in addition to Uzbek. 
The  Government  has  struggled  to  maintain  this  policy  by  providing  subsidies  for  minority 
language textbook publishing especially in times of fiscal strains. Reform of LOI policies will help 
ensure greater equity in the provision of education to the different national language groups and 
will also contribute to overall system cost reduction. 
 
8. 
Information and Communication Technology (ICT) development in the school system is 
also a stated priority of the Government as a central requirement for human development and 
education  provision  in  the  21st  century.  However,  how  ICT  development  can  and  should  be 
integrated  in  the  curriculum  to  improve  learning  and  teaching  is  unclear.  In  addition,  huge 
investment and recurrent cost implications of this policy requirement are yet to be fully explored 
and  understood.  Present  ICT  support  is  mostly  driven  by  funding  agencies  and  short-term 
based, with little or no concern for longer-term financial sustainability. A practical, affordable and 
sustainable strategy for ICT development in schools is urgently needed. 
 
Learning and Teaching Materials. Textbooks are the dominant means of learning and 
9. 
teaching and thus the key material input in influencing quality and relevance of basic education. 
In former Soviet times and prior to 1998, the Government provided textbooks. Due to increasing 
fiscal and financial strains, the Government decided to cease the free provision of textbooks and 
adopted  the  policy  of  user  charges.  Immediately  afterwards,  textbooks  were  in  short  supply 
because the majority of parents could not afford to buy them. The textbook rental scheme (TRS) 
successfully  introduced  in  2000  effectively  addressed  the  affordability  issue  by  reducing 
parental expenditure on textbooks to a rental fee. The fee was approximately 5 times cheaper 
than the total purchase price of a set of textbooks from the market. The TRS was subsequently 
extended  nationwide  to  cover  grades  2–5  and  9,  with  national  coverage  of  grade  2–9  to  be 
completed  by  the  end  of  2007.  Further  cost  savings  in  basic  textbook  provision  could  be 
achieved  by  reducing  textbook  requirements;  this  could  be  achieved  by  revising  curriculum 
specifications  and  making  other  policy  improvements.  Currently,  textbooks  are  still  in  need  of 
improved  professional  skills  in  writing,  illustration,  page  design,  layout,  and  presentation  to 
make them more user friendly and thus enhance student interest and learning impact.  
 
10.  While textbooks will remain for many years the fundamental learning and teaching tool, 
modern,  open  access school  libraries  can  play  a  key  role as  resource  centers  in supporting a 
modern  curriculum  and  student-centered  learning.  As  such,  they  provide  a  wider  range  of 
alternative  materials,  viewpoints,  and  approaches  that  supplement  and  extend  the  basic

ESTABLISHMENT OF THE REPUBLICAN TEXTBOOK REVOLVING FUND FOUNDATION  

 
1. 
The  textbook  rental  scheme  (TRS)  was  piloted  successfully  in  2001  under  the  Basic 
Education Textbook Development Project to address the provision of affordable textbooks after 
the  Government  decided  to  stop  supplying  free  textbooks  starting  in  1998.  Under  the  TRS 
parents rent textbooks at a fee only a fraction of the full purchase price; textbooks are designed 
to last 4 years. Starting from 2002, the TRS is being gradually extended nationwide until 2007 
when all grades (2–9) in all schools will be covered by the TRS. The extension of TRS coverage 
to  grades  6,  7,  and  8  will  be  supported  by  the  Project  during  2005–2007.  The  rental  fees 
collected are kept in a Ministry of Public Education (MOPE) account with each school having a 
subaccount  identifying  its  portion  of  the  fees  collected.  As  of  1  July  2004,  a  total  of  SUM4.7 
billion (or 47% of the total costs of TRS introduced during 2001–2003) had been accumulated. 
This  amount  is  expected  to  increase  steadily  until  the  first  cycle  of  textbook  replacement  (for 
grade 9) begins in 2006 when there will be a drawdown on the collected amount. At full national 
coverage the average balance of the rental fees collected is projected to be about $30 million, 
and  no  further  budgetary  support  will  be  required  except  for  the  continued  support,  which  the 
Government has committed to, for the socially unprotected. This amounts to about 15% of total 
enrolment  who  cannot  afford  to  pay  even  the  rental  fees.  The  main  sources  of  TRS  financing 
are the Government (budget and Asian Development Bank (ADB) loans) and parents who pay 
rental fees. While the Government provides the startup capital, once replacement of textbooks 
begins,  starting  in  2006,  no  further  budgetary  support  will  be  needed  except  for  the  socially 
unprotected.  
 
2. 
Based  on  the  experience  in  Uzbekistan  since  2001  and  lessons  learned  elsewhere,  a 
number  of  key  principles  have  been  identified  for  TRS  sustainability  and  the  provision  of 
affordable  textbooks  to  all  students  nationwide.  First,  rental  fee  collection  rates  have  to  be 
sufficiently high (80% or more), which requires widespread support of parents. A key to win and 
maintain parental support is the guarantee that the rental fees will be used for the purpose for 
which they are intended, the sustainable supply of low-cost textbooks. Second, high collection 
rates  depend  critically  on  overall  supervision  and  management.  Experience  elsewhere  (e.g., 
Armenia,  Tajikistan)  has  highlighted  the  importance  of  systematic  supervision  and  monitoring. 
Third, continued government support will be required for supporting those students (about 15% 
based on Uzbekistan experience) who are too poor to pay even rental fees—to ensure equity 
and social protection. Fourth, affordable rental fees require long book life to allow for maximum 
cost  amortization,  which  in  turn  is  based  on  high  physical  production  specifications.  The 
collected rental fees will have to be maintained intact and without misappropriation or diversion 
into other uses. In education systems where financial resources are scarce there will always be 
pressure  to  divert  accumulated  rental  fees  to  other  urgent  needs  unless  they  are  specifically 
protected. Diversion of funding undermines the TRS’ capacity to purchase replacement copies 
in the required quantities, which in turn undermines the entire TRS concept. Finally, centralized 
versus  school-based  management  of  TRS  fees  will  have  distinct  advantages  in  terms  of  the 
capacity  to  maintain  the  fund  value  through  financial  and  risk  management,  and  internal 
systematic monitoring and control.

they need to participate fully in the economy and in society.

financing.  Improving  the  quality  and  relevance  of  the  basic  education  system  will  be  key  priorities  for

Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Due to a system of compulsory education, literacy is almost universal and no significant difference exists 
between  girls’  and  boys’  educational  attendance  and  attainment  at  primary  and  secondary  education 
levels.3  Equality of gender representation in learning and teaching materials is not perceived as a major 
issue.  
 
During the Basic Education Textbook Development Project (BETDP), research studies were conducted on 
gender representation and stereotyping in textbooks, and the recommendations of these research studies 
have been incorporated into the specific gender components of the textbook evaluation criteria. Approval 
criteria  and  methodology  are  being  included  in  the  specific  evaluation  requirements  on  the  fair  and 
equitable  presentation  of  gender  in  textbooks,  teacher  guides,  and  other  learning  materials  and  marks. 
The  evaluation  for  gender  sensitivity  and  appropriateness  is  part  of  the  process  of  approval.  Training
